newsitem.title: GERMANY: Three Kurds accused of PKK crimes in German trial.
newsitem.headline: Three Kurds accused of PKK crimes in German trial.

text.p: Three Kurdish men went on trial in Germany on Tuesday accused of being ringleaders of the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and masterminding a 1993 campaign of arson attacks by the banned group.
Prosecutor Thomas Beck said Haydar Ergul, Nihat Asut and Ahmet Yavus had ordered the attacks which targeted Turkish businesses and banks in Germany and resulted in one death.
"The accused are ringleaders of a terrorist organisation which aims to commit murder," Beck said.
The three men, aged between 34 and 40, praised the PKK's fight for Kurdish autonomy in southeastern Turkey in their opening statement to the court.
But they denied the charges against them and said they were not even members of the PKK. Ergul vowed to go on hunger strike for a week in support of fellow Kurds imprisoned in Turkey.
More than two million Turkish citizens live in Germany and about one fifth of them are Kurds.
Police say Kurdish extremists wanting to vent their anger at the Turkish government often target the property of mainstrean Turks whom they view as being loyal to Ankara.
